Even if a discharge petition secured the votes to pass, which is far from certain, it would take time to reach the House floor. That effectively guarantees it’ll be pushed into next year, with Republicans hoping to adjourn after this week.

Rep. Andy Harris, R-Md., who was just re-elected to serve as House Freedom Caucus chairman for another year, said he isn’t worried about his colleagues signing a discharge petition or even passing a bill to extend ACA funds through the House.

“It’s their right as a member to sign a discharge petition. I’m not afraid of a vote on a discharge petition. These will pass in the House, and then they’ll be killed over in the Senate,” Harris said. “The Senate’s already taken a position on extending the Affordable Care Act to enhance subsidies, and they rejected it.”

Harris added that “it’s possible that we put a package together in January or February” dealing with health care, but he said it must be broader than just addressing ACA enrollees in order to secure his vote.
Asked if he’s worried that moderate Republicans may sign onto Democrats’ discharge petition, Johnson told NBC News, “I don’t worry about anything.”

title: A medical examiner's testimony put a father behind bars for life. Now he says he 'made a mistake.'
summary: Dr. Bruce Levy’s finding that shaken baby syndrome killed Russell Maze’s son, Alex, was critical in the Tennessee man’s murder conviction. Levy now says Maze is innocent.
story: In the summer of 2024, Dr. Bruce Levy, the former chief medical examiner of Tennessee, got a call asking whether he remembered the death of a baby boy, Alex Maze.

The name, from nearly 25 years earlier, faintly stirred Levy’s memory. Levy had conducted an autopsy on the 19-month-old boy, and he had concluded that Alex’s death was a homicide, the result of being violently shaken.
Levy’s testimony was critical in helping Nashville prosecutors secure a murder conviction against Alex’s father, Russell Maze, who was sentenced to life in prison.
For more on this story, watch “Hallie Jackson NOW” on NBC News Now today at 5 p.m. ET

For decades, Maze has denied abusing his son. He had been home alone with Alex in May 1999 when the baby suddenly stopped breathing. At the hospital, a pediatrician who specialized in identifying child abuse found what she said were clear signs that Alex was the victim of shaken baby syndrome. Levy later agreed.
Now, decades later, Levy was being asked to re-examine Alex’s death amid an initiative in Nashville investigating potential wrongful convictions. Intrigued, Levy said yes.

This month, in his first public comments on the case, Levy told NBC News that after having received information he never knew about Alex’s medical history, he came to a startling conclusion: He was wrong about Alex’s being abused, and he believes Maze is innocent.

“I have to remember that I’m not perfect and I can make mistakes,” Levy said. “And the best that I can do, is when I come to realize that, is to admit that I have made a mistake and try to do what I can to rectify that.”

Thousands of caregivers have been arrested based on the long-held medical belief that three symptoms — brain swelling, bleeding in the brain and bleeding behind the eyes — indicate that a young child was deliberately shaken.

But in the decades since Maze was convicted, there has been a growing acknowledgment among experts that the symptoms once believed to be proof of shaken baby syndrome, also known as abusive head trauma, can appear in children for other reasons, like complex medical conditions. And with that shift in understanding, a movement has been growing to re-examine — and potentially reverse — some shaken baby convictions, particularly when the evidence of abuse now appears questionable.

In October, NBC News’ “The Last Appeal” podcast investigated the high-profile case of Robert Roberson, a condemned man on Texas’ death row who was convicted of fatally shaking and abusing his 2-year-old daughter, Nikki, in 2002. On Oct. 9, Texas’ highest criminal court halted the latest attempt to execute Roberson, sending his case back to a lower court for another review. “We are confident that an objective review of the science and medical evidence will show there was no crime,” Gretchen Sween, Roberson’s attorney, said at the time.
Maze is still waiting for a similar breakthrough.

After he reviewed Maze’s case, Levy wrote an affidavit in September 2024 recanting his homicide finding and determining that Alex had succumbed to a “natural” death. He joined an ongoing effort by the Nashville district attorney’s office, which has been working to free Maze.

title: CDC formally stops recommending hepatitis B vaccines for all newborns
summary: Instead of recommending the hepatitis B vaccine for all newborns, the CDC's guidance is now to consult a health care provider about the birth dose.
story: Instead of recommending the hepatitis B vaccine for all newborns, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention now officially advises women who test negative for the virus to consult health care providers about whether their babies should get their first doses within 24 hours of birth.

The agency’s vaccine advisory committee — whose members Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. appointed this year after he fired the previous ones — voted for the recommendation earlier this month, upending more than three decades of agency guidance. Acting CDC Director Jim O’Neill accepted the change on Tuesday — the final step for it to become the agency’s policy.
“We are restoring the balance of informed consent to parents whose newborns face little risk of contracting hepatitis B,” O'Neill said in a statement.

The CDC had recommended the birth dose of the vaccine since 1991. Many public health experts criticized the advisory committee’s decision: After the meeting, a chorus of doctors, political leaders and health officials called on O’Neill to ignore the suggested change and maintain the CDC’s recommendation, to no avail.

The CDC now suggests waiting until at least 2 months of age for babies’ first hepatitis B shots if they do not receive the birth dose. However, it still recommends that babies born to mothers who test positive for hepatitis B or whose infection statuses are unknown get hepatitis B vaccines within the first day of life.

The agency is still reviewing a secondary recommendation from the panel: that parents consult with health care providers about the possibility of testing children for antibodies to hepatitis B before they decide whether to get second doses of the vaccine. The hepatitis B vaccine is typically given to babies as a three-dose series.

The new policy is one of the most notable examples of the way CDC guidance is diverging from widespread medical consensus. The advisory committee's discussion of hepatitis B vaccines was rife with misinformation and cherry-picked data, and it ignored decades of evidence that hepatitis B vaccines are safe and effective when they are given shortly after birth.

Many public health experts say delaying the hepatitis B vaccine until babies are older could lead to a resurgence of infections and possibly more deaths from liver disease or cancer. Pediatric cases of acute hepatitis B plummeted after the CDC began recommending a universal birth dose, falling by 99% from 1990 to 2019. Hepatitis B can be passed from mother to child during delivery, and not all pregnant women get tested for it. There is no cure.

“Ending the recommendation for newborns makes it more likely the number of cases will begin to increase again. This makes America sicker,” Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., a liver doctor who has treated patients with hepatitis B, said on X earlier this month. Cassidy is one of many medical professionals who publicly asked O’Neill not to adopt the advisory panel’s recommendations.

Pediatricians are expected to keep recommending that parents vaccinate their newborns for hepatitis B. The Department of Health and Human Services has said the new recommendations will not affect insurance coverage of the shots. The vaccine will also continue to be offered to newborns through the Vaccines for Children Program, which provides free shots for uninsured or underinsured kids.

The hepatitis B decision was the latest in a series of CDC policy changes that have not been backed by science, leading some public health experts to suggest that the agency’s guidance should no longer be trusted.

After Kennedy gutted the long-standing membership of the CDC’s vaccine panel — formally known as the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices — in June, he replaced it with a group that has largely expressed skepticism of vaccines.

O’Neill, a former investment executive who does not have a medical background, previously worked at the Department of Health and Human Services under President George W. Bush. He became acting CDC director in August after Kennedy abruptly fired the previous director, Susan Monarez. Kennedy said Monarez was fired for being untrustworthy, but Monarez said Kennedy dismissed her for refusing to blindly approve the vaccine advisory panel’s recommendations.

Last month, the CDC altered a webpage that had once unequivocally said vaccines do not cause autism, claiming instead that studies have not ruled out a link. (In fact, decades of research have found no association.)

In October, O’Neill called on vaccine manufacturers to develop separate shots for measles, mumps and rubella, without evidence to support breaking up the combined vaccine. And in September, the CDC updated its guidance to tell pregnant women to consider avoiding acetaminophen — the active ingredient in Tylenol — because of a possible connection to autism in children. (The bulk of scientific literature to date has not found a definitive link.)

After decades of leaning on CDC guidance, many states have begun to defer to recommendations from newly formed public health alliances or professional medical societies like the American Academy of Pediatrics. The AAP continues to recommend a first dose of the hepatitis B vaccine within 24 hours of birth, followed by additional doses at 1 to 2 months and 6 to 18 months.

title: Five worrying employment trends buried in the latest jobs report
summary: A deeper look at the federal jobs data reveals trends in teen and Black unemployment, factory jobs and lopsided sector breakdowns that could spell trouble.
story: On Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics released delayed jobs data from the last two months, showing the U.S. shed 105,000 jobs in October and added 64,000 jobs in November.
But a deeper look at the employment data reveals several trends that could spell trouble for the U.S. labor market if they maintain their current trajectories.
Job creation began to falter in April
Stepping back from the report and taking a look at 2025 so far, job growth appears to have started faltering in April, around when President Donald Trump announced his "Liberation Day" tariffs.
The year started off strong, with job creation in the first four months averaging about 122,000 per month. That's when the problems began to appear.

From May through November, job growth slowed to a pace of about 32,000 a month. Put another way, about a quarter as many positions have been created monthly since May than during the first four months of the year.
But the monthly data itself can obscure overall trends, with numbers that rise and fall from month to month and political spin on all sides.
Overall, since May there have been four months when payrolls increased and three months when they fell.

Those three months of losses are a sharp departure from the recent past. To find the last time there was any month when the country lost more jobs than it gained, you'd have to go back to 2020, when the Covid-19 pandemic paralyzed the U.S. economy and cost millions of workers their jobs.
Black unemployment is rising sharply
The unemployment rate among Black workers has risen higher and faster than the overall rate of joblessness in recent months.
In May, Black unemployment fell to a low for the year of 6.0%, a rate that was just 1.8 percentage points above the overall unemployment rate that month.
By November, the unemployment rate among Black workers stood at 8.3%, a full 3.7 points higher than that of the broader U.S. workforce.
The rate of job losses for Black workers is also outpacing the population overall. From May through November, the U.S. unemployment rate rose just 0.4%, but Black unemployment climbed 2.3%.
Job gains are concentrated in just two sectors

In what JPMorgan Chase called a "concerning development," detailed data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics revealed that nearly all the private job growth over the past two months was in just two sectors: health care and social services.

In November, home health care aides and nursing home positions led the growth in health care jobs. Among social services positions, individual and family services, a category that includes services for the elderly and disabled people, were the fastest-growing category last month.
Indeed, Sage Economics noted that almost all of the job growth this year came from the health care and social services sectors.
Factory jobs are disappearing
If health and social welfare jobs are the big winners this year among private-sector positions, manufacturing and white-collar services are the losers.

Outside of government employment, which fell further than any other sector, the biggest sector losses this year were an 80,000-job decline in business services jobs and a loss of 63,000 jobs in manufacturing, according to economist Zach Fritz at Sage Economics.
Those manufacturing jobs were eliminated despite the Trump administration's pledge to revitalize domestic manufacturing in the president's second term.

As for the white-collar job cuts, those come amid the rapid adoption of artificial intelligence across workplaces. While it's not immediately clear how many jobs lost are directly tied to AI, a recent estimate from Goldman Sachs said that if AI were adopted across the board, it "could displace 6-7% of the US workforce."
Teen unemployment has surged
The unemployment rate for teens jumped to 16.3% in November after having hit 13.2% in the most recent jobs report in September, before the government shutdown.
That’s the highest teen unemployment level since August 2020, when Covid had millions of worried parents keeping their teenagers home and out of the workforce.

title: 'Blood everywhere': Bondi shooting survivors recount massacre on the beach
summary: SYDNEY — Hundreds remained on Bondi Beach long after the sun had set Tuesday
story: SYDNEY — Hundreds remained on Bondi Beach long after the sun had set Tuesday.

Many stood silently beneath the waning moon, police helicopters  whirring overhead. Some laid bouquets of flowers, which local stores were giving out for free. All were there to pay tribute to the 15 people killed at a Hanukkah celebration on Sunday.

title: When and How to Watch 'The Voice' Season 28 Finale
summary: 'The Voice' Season 28 finale takes place Monday Dec. 15, 2025. Find out how to watch on NBC, stream online, and what time both nights air.
story: Season 28 of ‘The Voice” is almost coming to an end.

This season has been jam-packed with powerhouse performances and emotional eliminations since its Sept. 22 premiere. Now, the competition's top six contestants are delivering their final performances in hopes of being crowned the winner.
The first four final contestants were announced last week. Two additional contestants — chosen by viewers — were revealed during the part one live finale on Dec. 15.
The results of the voting will be revealed tonight, Dec. 16, during the star-studded finale episode, which features performances by girl group XG and singer Khalid.

Only one artist — and that artist's coach — will be crowned the winner. Will two-time champion coaches Michael Bublé or Niall Horan win for the third time? Or will they be bested by one of their fellow judges, Reba McEntire or Snoop Dogg?
Here's everything to know about the Season 28 finale.
What Time Does ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale Air?
Part one of the two-night finale of “The Voice” aired at 9 p.m. ET on Dec. 15. The second final episode will air also at 9 p.m. ET on Dec. 16.
Where to Watch ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale
Viewers can watch the episodes live on NBC. Each episode will be available to stream the day after it airs on Peacock.
Ahead of the winner being announced on Tuesday's episode, a special finale pre-show will air featuring Ariana Madix and Dylan Efron.
The special will start at 8 p.m. ET on NBC and also stream the following day on Peacock. Madix and Efron will break down Monday's performances and speak with the finalists.
Both NBC and Peacock are owned by NBCUniversal, TODAY’s parent company.
Who Is Competing in the Finale?
Four of the final contestants were announced during the Playoff rounds, while the final two were revealed on Dec. 15.
Aubrey Nicole (Team Reba)Aiden Ross (Team Niall)Jazz McKenzie (Team Bublé) Ralph Edwards (Team Snoop).Dek of Hearts (Team Niall)Max Chambers (Team Bublé)
Aubrey Nicole (Team Reba)
Aiden Ross (Team Niall)
Jazz McKenzie (Team Bublé)
Ralph Edwards (Team Snoop).
Dek of Hearts (Team Niall)
Max Chambers (Team Bublé)
What’s Going to Happen During ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale?
The live two-part finale kicked off with the show’s top six contestants pulling out all the stops for their final vocal performances.

XG will perform their brand-new song “Gala” during one of the nights. There will also be guest performances by former “The Voice” winner Sofronio and Neal Schon and Journey on Dec. 16, as well as Zac Brown, Riley Green and Noah Cyrus.

Fans have been voting for who they believe the winner should be at NBC.com/VoiceVote or on the official “Voice” app. Whoever wins the most votes will be crowned Season 28’s winner during the live Dec. 16 episode.

title: Golden Globe Swag Bags Are Worth 'Just Under $1 Million.' What's In Them?
summary: What's in the 2026 Golden Globes swag bags? See a complete list and see all 35 items included, plus why they're worth just under $1 million.
story: The recipients of the 2026 Golden Globes won't be the only winners in the building.

A swag bag worth nearly $1 million will not only go to the winners of the coveted trophies, but also the presenters at the annual ceremony. It's a slight reduction from the 2025 bag, which was valued at $1 million.
Once again, the luxury lifestyle magazine Robb Report has curated what it has dubbed "The Ultimate Gift Bag" for the event, which has nearly doubled in value in the last two years.
The luxury swag bag will be given out to the winners and presenters at the 83rd annual Golden Globes, which will air live at 8 p.m. ET on Jan. 11 on CBS and stream on Paramount+.

The 2026 edition features nearly double the amount of luxury travel getaways compared to last year's bag. It features 35 items overall between travel experiences, wellness goodies and wine, spirits and cigars.

“From an expanded slate of global getaways to standout moments in wellness, beauty, and spirits, recipients have the opportunity to create a luxury experience that feels entirely their own," Luke Bahrenburg, President of Robb Report and Head of Luxury Sales at PMC, said in a news release. "Every detail reflects our commitment to celebrating the best in class, bringing together remarkable destinations and rare, indulgent finds to create an unforgettable gifting experience.”
Here's what to know about the 2026 version of the Golden Globes swag bag.
Who will receive the gift bag?
The winners and the presenters at the 83rd annual ceremony will each receive a bag containing the 35 offerings available on a first-come, first-served basis.
What is included in the gift bag?
Packed insider Atlas Bespoke’s Signature Duffel Bag is a gift book detailing all 35 of offerings included in the gift bag.

The most exclusive of the travel offerings, which are available to only one recipient each, are a six-night stay across luxury lodges Flockhill, ROKI and Minaret in New Zealand worth $31,307, and a three-night stay at The Estate Villa in Montego Bay, Jamaica, valued at $30,000.

All winners and presenters are eligible for all offerings in this year’s collection, and the items available to a limited number of recipients are given out on a first-come, first-served basis, according to the Golden Globes.

For the luxury car enthusiasts, one recipient will be allowed to test drive high-end vehicles at The Concours Club in Boca Raton, Fla., in a perk worth $31,400. One recipient will also be awarded two tickets to the Robb Report's Car of the Year competition.

Another prize exclusive to one recipient will be nine ultra-rare bottles of French wine from the Bordeaux winery Liber Pater that are valued at $210,000. Two tickets to the Jubilee at the Liber Pater estate in Bordeaux, valued at $117,000, will also be given to one recipient.

Other luxury travel options available to winners and presenters include a three-night stay at a beachfront villa in San Jose del Cabo, Mexico ($25,000), a five-day luxury yacht trip in Indonesia ($60,000), a two-night stay at an undersea residence on Conrad Maldives Rangali Island ($70,000), a three-night stay at an exclusive Hilton property in the Maldives ($80,000), and a four-nigh stay at a luxury hotel in Bali, Indonesia ($5,800).
Recipients will also be gifted a host of high-end skincare, haircare and perfume products, a rental experience at an ultra-private gym and massages at a pair of Waldorf Astoria locations.
Also included are a bottle of Cygnet 22 and 77 ($500) and a six-bottle case of whiskey from Isle of Harris Distillery ($1,080).

title: What Time Does 'Fallout' Season 2 Premiere? How to Watch
summary: When does Fallout Season 2 premiere? It's coming early. Here's what time it starts and how to watch the Amazon Prime show including an episode schedule.
story: Last year's season 1 debut of Prime Video's "Fallout" was an incredible success, becoming the streaming service's most successful program according to Nielsen’s "The Gauge" report in April 2024.
The sci-fi drama follows Los Angeles residents trying to survive after a nuclear war turned the city post-apocalyptic.
With the anticipation for Season 2 so high, Prime Video has an early holiday gift for fans and will release the season's premiere earlier than expected.
Here's everything you need to know to stream the upcoming season of "Fallout."
When does 'Fallout' Season 2 premiere?
Prime Video announced that the season premiere will release one day earlier than originally scheduled.
You can see the premiere at Tuesday, December 16, at 6 p.m. PT / 9 p.m. ET now, all thanks to "fan demand," per a press release.
What time do 'Fallout' episodes come out?
While the season premiere will release on a Tuesday, fans can expect the rest of the seasons' episodes to premiere on Prime Video Wednesdays at 12am PT / 3am ET.
What is the 'Fallout' Season 2 episode schedule?
The rest of the season's schedule is as follows:

Episode 202: Wednesday, Dec. 24 at 12 a.m. PT / 3 a.m. ET
Episode 203 — Wednesday, Dec. 31 at 12 a.m. PT / 3 a.m. ET

title: Stars of ‘Stand by Me’ and ‘The Princess Bride’ React to Rob Reiner’s Death
summary: Stars of "The Princess Bride" and "Stand by Me" reacted to director Rob Reiner’s death, sharing what he meant to them.
story: Rob Reiner’s death has reverberated among his fans and the scores of actors he worked with in his roster of legendary movies.
Reiner, 78, and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were found dead Dec. 14 in their Los Angeles home, according to police. Their son Nick has been arrested on suspicion of murdering them.

Reiner, the son of comedy icon Carl Reiner, rose to fame in the 1970s on “All in the Family” before making his mark as a filmmaker. He leaves behind a roster of movies that have entertained and moved fans for decades.

Reiner also had an ability to showcase undiscovered, young talent. Robin Wright made her film debut in 1987's “The Princess Bride,” which also starred Fred Savage before viewers were introduced to him in 1988 in “The Wonder Years.” “Stand by Me,” released in 1986, featured Wil Wheaton, Jerry O'Connell, Kiefer Sutherland and John Cusack before they were household names. Stars of those movies were stunned by his death. Take a look at how they remembered Reiner.
"The Princess Bride"
“No words…” he captioned a Dec. 15 Instagram post showing a black-and-white photo of their chairs from the film’s set.

“I am deeply shocked and devastated. I cannot begin to imagine what the family is experiencing or what they will have to endure in the months and years ahead,” she said in a Dec. 15 statement to NBC News.

“It is truly heartbreaking. Rob was one of the most loving, compassionate, and kind people I have ever known. He was an extraordinary director and the impact he had on me has stayed with me throughout my career. My heart goes out to his family and loved ones during this incredibly difficult time.”

“He found me in a casting room in downtown Chicago and gave me the opportunity to be a part of something that has become so much bigger than anyone could have ever imagined,” he captioned a Dec. 15 Instagram photo of him as a child with Reiner.
“Who knew those two weeks in a bedroom set on the Shepperton Studio lot would last forever? His work was a gift to us all and I feel lucky to have been a part of it.”
“Changed my life. Rest in peace, Rob and Michele,” he captioned a photo of the film’s cast on Instagram Dec. 15.
“The tragedy of Rob and Michelle’s deaths are incomprehensible,” he wrote Dec. 15 on Instagram alongside a pair of photos of Reiner, including one of the director giving him a kiss on the cheek.

“I’m hearing Rob’s voice telling us all to do more, to repair the human soul, to repair our hearts, to repair our country, to repair our world, to keep fighting, to keep living for every soul taken from this earth. We must raise our voices for them. I’ll continue to try and follow Rob’s example as an artist and a humanitarian. I hope you do too.

“I don’t know what else to do other than try to cherish every moment we are alive, to be of service to every aspect of our existence and to never give up. When feeling lost one thing I might ask is ‘What would Rob do?’ and then do it.
“Stand by Me”
“Generation X grew up with Rob,” Wheaton wrote in a Dec. 15 blog post on his website.

“We watched him on All in the Family when we were little, and as we came of age, he made movies about our lives as we were living them: movies about growing up, falling in and out of love, about seeing the goodness that exists inside every single person, if only they are open to it. He told us stories about the strength of the human spirit, and he made us laugh. Oh, how he made us laugh.”
Wheaton said he didn’t interact often with Reiner, but his impact was profound.

“I only really knew Rob Reiner for one summer, in 1985, when we made Stand By Me. We only saw each other a handful of times in the last 40 years, and outside of those rare meetings, we only spoke a couple of times. Even though I haven’t spoken to him in years, I will miss him forever.” Eagle-eyed fans will note the “I will miss him forever” line is what the adult version of Wheaton’s character wrote in his story as “Stand by Me” drew to a close.
Wheaton also wrote that he had intended to reunite with Reiner to celebrate the film’s 40th anniversary.

“I was hoping that we would see each other next year, at something celebrating Stand By Me turning 40, so I could see him and properly thank him for everything he gave me — in my career, sure (it only exists because of Rob), but in my life, as well,” he wrote.

“Love you, Rob. Sincerely,” O’Connell captioned a throwback photo of the two of them on Instagram Dec. 15. Fans will no doubt recognize the “sincerely” as a reference to the word O’Connell’s character, Vern, often says throughout the film.

“ROB WAS A HERO 2 MANY, A GR8 DIRECTOR 2 THOSE WHO HAD THE LUCKY CHANCE 2 WORK W HIM, AN AMAZING COMEDIC ACTOR & WRITER, AN AMAZING FATHER 2 THE BEST OF HIS ABILITIES, & A GR8 LOYAL SON 2 HIS OWN FAMOUS FATHER! BUT THAT SUMMER IN 1985, 40 YEARS AGO THIS YR, ON THE SET OF #STANDBYME HE WAS ALL OF R FATHERS THAT SUMMER!” he wrote on Instagram Dec. 15.

“Like so many my heart was broken when I heard the news about Rob Reiner and his wonderful wife, Michele,” he captioned a Dec. 15 Instagram post with a photo of Reiner and Phoenix at work on “Stand by Me.”
“Rob was one of the kindest gentleman I’ve ever had the pleasure of working with. When I was very young he gave me an opportunity that changed my life, and I will forever be grateful.”

“What made Rob a great man — was not his prodigious talents as an actor director writer producer — it was his huge heart, his endless generosity and his decency and humanity that made him great,” Cusack wrote Dec. 15 on X.

“He had soul — and saw the soul in others . He loved justice . Gave me my break in the business and took care of me like a son. A mensch in every sense . Honored to work with him on his second and third films — sure thing and stand by me — Love you Rob.”
King, who wrote “The Body,” the story that was the basis for “Stand by Me,” mourned the death of Reiner, who also directed “Misery,” which was based on King’s book of the same name.

“I’m horrified and saddened by the death of Rob Reiner and Michele. Wonderful friend, political ally, and brilliant filmmaker (including 2 of mine). Rest in peace, Rob. You always stood by me,” he wrote Dec. 15 on X.

title: Who Is Anthony Geary's Husband, Claudio Gama?
summary: Anthony Geary married his husband, Claudio Gama, in 2019. Here's what to know about their relationship and cat, Max.
story: Iconic soap opera star Anthony Geary passed away on Dec. 14 at the age of 78. He is survived by his husband, Claudio Gama.
Gama first shared the news with TV Insider, offering the following statement.
"It was a shock for me and our families and our friends. For more than 30 years, Tony has been my friend, my companion, my husband,” he said.
Geary passed away from complications from a scheduled medical procedure he had undergone three days before his death. The actor's representatives confirmed news of his death to NBC News on Dec. 15.
Geary, who appeared on “General Hospital” for decades as Luke Spencer, retired from the soap opera in 2015 and mostly avoided the spotlight.
Below, we're sharing everything to know about his life with Gama.
Geary and Gama Were Together for Over 30 Years

Gama reflected on their decades together in an Instagram video posted in February 2025. In the short clip, Gama spoke to the couple's cat and said he "finally said yes" to Geary's marriage proposal six years ago.
Geary Lived Together with Gama in Amsterdam
After retiring from "General Hospital" in 2015, Geary moved to Amsterdam with his longtime love.
While speaking with Soap Opera Digest in 2003, Geary opened up about his quiet life overseas.

“I live in the city (Amsterdam) that I’ve always wanted to live in my whole life and I have somebody who loves me and I have a life now, that I didn’t have before, no matter how many fan letters or Emmys or how many pages of dialogue to learn. I didn’t have what I have now. So, everything happened at the right time, I guess,” he said.
They Shared a Cat Named Max
Geary and Gama's cat, Max, appears in many of Gama's Instagram posts.
Recently, Gama shared a video of the cat, who "had to check the tree" when the couple decorated their Christmas tree.
Gama Regularly Posted About His Life With Geary
Over the last few years, Gama has given Geary's fans a look into his life in Amsterdam via Instagram.
Gama also shares updates about his life and travels on his blog, MMaxi Travels Around The World.

title: Teacher Explains What Happened After Khloé Kardashian's Flirtatious Comment on His IG Post
summary: A Santa Cruz teacher went viral for a post that Khloé Kardashian flirted with him about with a public comment. He tells TODAY.com what happened next.
story: A Santa Cruz teacher has gone viral after his simple request to have someone ask how his day went was answered by none other than Khloé Kardashian.

Jacob Myers, who has been teaching for two and a half years after working as an assistant teacher and substitute, started posting videos on Instagram in October about a day in the life of a high school teacher.
He has shared fit checks and funny clips about his frustrating mornings, and also heartfelt videos about supporting his students and feeling stressed.

But one of his recent videos caught the attention of over 100,000 social media users, including Kardashian. Myers shared a clip of him posing in his classroom. Text over the video included some facts about him, like his Italian roots and past life as a collegiate athlete. In the caption, he wrote, “Somewhere out there is the woman who’s gonna ask how my school day was.”

Kardashian decided to be the one to pose the pivotal question, writing “How was your day??” in the comments. Her reply received over 80,000 likes and Instagram users immediately chimed in, suggesting that the two meet. Even Kardashian’s close friend Malika Haqq encouraged the potential connection. “Isn’t she the sweetest,” she asked the high school teacher and coach, playing wing woman for her bestie.

Myers left a flirtatious reply: “Mine is great now. How was yours?” Then he uploaded a follow-up video, also filmed in his classroom, giving Kardashian a longer response. He shared that he was interested in meeting up in person and pitched being her plus-one to a Kardashian Christmas party.
He tagged Kardashian, Haqq and momager Kris Jenner in the post. “This is your sign to help a teacher out and tag @khloekardashian. Shooters gotta shoot,” he playfully wrote in the caption.
Myers tells TODAY.com that he decided to post the initial video on a whim when he was preparing for final exams and feeling swamped. He couldn’t have imagined the amount of replies he received.

“(I) honestly never expected the attention. It’s been very overwhelming and exciting at the same time, because I just post the videos for the fun of them,” he shares. “My students are kind of my main priority. I’m a teacher first and foremost.”
His students were the ones who encouraged him to start using his social media to post about his job.
“They were like, ‘Why don’t you make Tiktok videos?’” he recalls them asking. They showed him other TikTokers who are teachers and he realized how many other educators can relate to his experience.

He continues, “I started to create content, and I ended up finding a community of teachers out there that were going through the same things. Just being stressed out as a teacher, but still enjoying it, and I was able to talk to them. Then it ended up creating a little support group in a way. Also, we’re able to trade lesson plans and info. It’s been a huge help to talk with teachers from around the world and connect with them.”
When he saw that Kardashian had noticed his content, he thought he might as well shoot his shot.
“You never get that many opportunities in my world,” he says. “So I was like, ‘Why not? What’s the worst that could happen?’”

After his interaction with the reality television star, his students, and co-workers, began teasing him that he was all over their For You Pages. He says during a school rally students gave gifts to all the teachers. They presented Myers with a Photoshopped picture of him and Kardashian.
He doesn’t mind the "overwhelming" attention or his students poking fun at him. But he says he hopes that his other videos resonate with people.
“I don’t want to be known (as) the teacher that asked out Khloé Kardashian. I’d rather be known as a great teacher and a great coach, which I think I am,” he says. “That’s my passion.”

Myers, who has nearly 90,000 followers on Instagram now, adds, “It’s been an exciting opportunity for me to actually shine a light on education and show people what I teach. There’s a lot of other teachers out there that don’t post and you don’t actually see what they do. And there’s a lot of other teachers that are just like me, who are teaching three different subjects and coaching multiple sports and running programs.”
He hopes his followers understand how much work educators put into helping their students.
As for a future date with Kardashian? He hasn’t heard anything yet.
“Khloé’s comment was incredibly kind, and of course I’d love the opportunity to meet her,” he says, adding that he is grateful for all the support he has received.

title: How Rob Reiner Rediscovered Love with Wife Michele: Marriage Became 'Better and Better'
summary: Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were married 36 years. He revealed how they met and why he changed the ending of "When Harry Met Sally."
story: Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were married for 36 years — a romance that began after he struggled to find love after his divorce.
It came to a horrific end over the weekend. The couple was found dead in their Los Angeles home Sunday and appeared to have died from stab wounds, a source close to the Reiner family told NBC News.
Nick Reiner, their son, has been arrested and booked on suspicion of murdering his parents.
Reiner, who was 78 when he died, said that before meeting his second wife, he didn’t think he’d find love again.
The actor and director was previously married to actress and director Penny Marshall. They wed in 1971 and divorced in 1981.

The aftermath of that split and his struggles to find a new partner were his inspiration for making “When Harry Met Sally” — the beloved romantic comedy he directed, starring Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan.

''I was in the middle of my single life. I'd been divorced for a while. I'd been out a number of times, all these disastrous, confusing relationships one after another,” Reiner told The New York Times in 1989.
As a single man, he was making “an utter mess” of his personal life and wanted to make a movie about what men and women go through, he added in an interview with People.

Reiner called himself the “prototype for Harry” in the movie, a man shocked by his divorce and unable to find love: “I couldn't see how I would get with anybody ever again. It became the basis for the film,” the director told AARP in 2014.
But about three-quarters of the way through making the movie, he met his second wife-to-be, the friend of a colleague.
The love story began when Reiner told Barry Sonnenfeld, the film’s cinematographer, about the struggles in his personal life.
“And he says to me, 'I know this girl. Her name is Michele Singer, and you're going to marry her.' And I said, 'What, are you nuts?'” Reiner recalled to The New York Times.
But when she came to the set one day, he was quickly smitten.

“I'll never forget it. It was a scene on a stoop in front of a brownstone. Billy and Meg are having an argument. And I look over, and I see this girl, and whoo! I was attracted immediately. And Barry says, 'That's Michele.' I said, 'That's Michele?'”
After meeting her, Reiner thought, "I see how this could work again," he told AARP.
Michele Singer was a photographer, producer and actress. The couple married in May 1989 and had three children.
"As you go along, the relationship becomes better and better because you really become best friends. And that has happened,” Reiner told AARP about his second marriage.
“She has helped raise me. The thing I talk about, how women show you what's important, she has done for me."
In 2024, Reiner revealed the love story with his wife inspired him to change the ending of “When Harry Met Sally.”

The original script had the characters Harry Burns and Sally Albright going their separate ways rather than the happier finale fans know — Harry professing his love on New Year’s Eve, telling Sally he wanted to spend the rest of his life with her and the pair becoming a couple.
“It was going to be the two of them seeing each other after years, talking, and then walking away from each other,” he said on “Who’s Talking to Chris Wallace.”
“I met my wife, Michele… while we were making the film, and I changed the ending.”
Reiner also directed “The Princess Bride,” “A Few Good Men” and “This Is Spinal Tap.”
Family friend Maria Shriver remembered the couple as "two deeply talented,  kind, fun, loving, good, patriotic people who loved each other deeply."

title: Rob Reiner Originally Wrote a Sad Ending for ‘When Harry Met Sally.’ Why He Changed It
summary: The late Rob Reiner spoke in an interview about his original sad ending for "When Harry Met Sally" and why his wife inspired him to change it.
story: Harry Burns and Sally Albright almost had a different fate.
Rob Reiner, the director of “When Harry Met Sally” who died Dec. 14, discussed the beloved rom-com in a Feb. 16 episode of CNN’s “Who’s Talking to Chris Wallace.”
Reiner revealed during the conversation that the “tear jerking” happy ending almost didn’t happen for Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan’s characters.
“The original ending of the film that we had was that Harry and Sally didn’t get together,” he said.
That original conclusion was personal to Reiner.
“I had been married for 10 years, I had been single for 10 years, and I couldn’t figure out how I was ever going to be with anybody, and that gave birth to ‘When Harry Met Sally,’” he explained.
Reiner was once married to the late Penny Marshall. They tied the knot in 1971 and split in 1981.
“I hadn’t met anybody, and so it was going to be the two of them seeing each other after years, talking and then walking away from each other,” he told Wallace.

This alternate ending might come as a shock to fans. In the finale fans remember, Harry (Crystal) rushes to a New Year’s Eve party where he delivers an iconic speech professing his love to Sally (Ryan) with the line, “I came here tonight because when you realize you want to spend the rest of your life with somebody, you want the rest of your life to start as soon as possible.”
Fittingly, that ending was born out of something that happened to Reiner during filming.

“I met my wife, Michele, who I’ve been married to now 35 years,” Reiner said, referring to actor Michele Singer Reiner, who he wed in 1989. “I met her while we were making the film, and I changed the ending.”

Rob Reiner and wife Michele Singer Reiner were found dead Dec. 14 in their Los Angeles home with apparent stab wounds, a source close to the family confirmed to NBC News. Their son Nick Reiner was arrested and booked Dec. 15 on suspicion of their murder.

Reiner was a beloved figure in Hollywood, having helmed so many classics like “The Princess Bride” and “Stand By Me.” “When Harry Met Sally” remains a darling in the rom-com genre with multiple memorable scenes, including Harry’s declaration of love and Sally’s famous diner scene shot at Katz’s Delicatessen in New York.
Ryan and Crystal have yet to speak publicly on Reiner’s death.

Ryan reflected on the movie while paying homage to her co-star, Crystal, an honoree at the 46th Kennedy Center Honors in December 2023. She referenced the scene where her character fakes an orgasm while sitting across from Crystal’s character.

“This scene came really naturally to me, and I really have Billy to thank for that,” she said of the moment. “I’ve actually never been around anyone who made faking an orgasm easier. So, thank you, Billy.”
Ryan later attributed the success of the film to a few factors, including Reiner’s “brilliant direction,” a “perfect script” from the late Nora Ephron and “chemistry.”
“Chemistry is ... well, no one really knows what chemistry is, but Harry and Sally had it,” she explained.
This story was originally published Feb. 17, 2024, and has been updated.

title: Carl Carlton, 'Bad Mama Jama' and 'Everlasting Love' Singer, Dies
summary: Carl Carlton, legendary singer known for his hits “She’s A Bad Mama Jama (She’s Built, She’s Stacked)” and “Everlasting Love,” has died.
story: Carl Carlton, legendary singer known for his hits “She’s A Bad Mama Jama (She’s Built, She’s Stacked)” and “Everlasting Love,” has died. He was 73.
His son, Carlton Hudgens II, confirmed his father’s death on his Facebook on Dec. 14.
“RIP Dad, Legend Carl Carlton singer of ‘She’s a Bad Mama Jama.’ Long hard fight in life and you will be missed,” Hudgens II wrote, also clarifying his father’s May 21, 1952 birthday.
Additionally, on his Facebook story, Hudgens II shared a photo of his singer father, writing, “R.I.P Dad, You can finally rest now. Always love you.”
A cause of death has not been shared at this time.

The R&B and funk star, born Carlton Hudgens, began his career under the moniker Little Carl” Carlton. Among his first singles were “I Think of How I Love Her” and “I Love True Love,” followed by “So What” and “Don’t You Need a Boy Like Me.”

The Detroit native's cover of Robert Knight’s “Everlasting Love,” became his highest-charting hit, landing at No. 6 on Billboard Hot 100 in November 1974. “She’s A Bad Mama Jama” also reached No. 22 on the chart in 1981 and earned him a Grammy nomination for best R&B vocal performance, male.
Over the course of his career, he released several albums with Carlton’s final one being “God Is Good” in 2010.
Upon hearing news of his death, the funk group Confunkshun paid tribute to the singer on Facebook.

“With heavy hearts, we mourn the passing of the legendary Carl Carlton. His voice, talent, and contributions to soul and R&B music will forever be a part of our lives and the soundtrack of so many memories,” they wrote. “Our deepest condolences to his family, friends, and fans around the world. Rest in power, Carl. Your legacy lives on.”
DJ D-Nice also remembered the icon, writing on his Instagram, Wow… Rest peacefully to the legendary Carl Carlton.”

“This is one of those timeless classics I truly enjoy spinning,” he wrote alongside a photo of “She’s A Bad Mama Jama” on vinyl. “‘She’s built, she’s stacked, got all the curves a man would like…’ Part of the soundtrack of my youth. Thank you for the music! Gone, but forever in rotation.”

title: Anthony Geary, Who Played Luke Spencer on ‘General Hospital,’ Dies at 78
summary: Anthony Geary, who found fame as one half of the daytime TV super couple Luke and Laura on "General Hospital" in the 1980s, has died.
story: Anthony Geary, who found fame as one half of the daytime TV super couple Luke and Laura on "General Hospital" in the 1980s, has died. His representatives confirmed to NBC News on Monday, Dec. 15.
Geary passed away due to complications from a scheduled medical procedure three days earlier, TV Insider reported. He was 78.

Geary's husband, Claudio Gama, confirmed Geary's death to the website, saying, “It was a shock for me and our families and our friends. For more than 30 years, Tony has been my friend, my companion, my husband.”
The Utah-born Geary got his professional start in the 1960s by appearing in small parts on the TV shows “All in the Family,” “Dan August,” “Mod Squad" and “The Partridge Family.”
He appeared on the soap opera “Bright Promise” from 1971-1972, before taking on the controversial role of George Curtis on “The Young and the Restless,” when the show debuted in 1973.
In 1978, he landed the part of the rakish street criminal Luke Spencer on “General Hospital.”
Though Luke’s romance with Laura Webber (Genie Francis) began in an unexpected way, the couple's adventurous life together became must-watch daytime television.
Their love story peaked with their on-screen wedding in 1981, which was watched by more than 30 million viewers, many skipping school or work to witness their nuptials, according to TV Guide.

The episode — which featured Hollywood legend (and “GH” super fan) Elizabeth Taylor in a guest-starring role as Helena Cassadine — remains the highest-rated soap opera episode in American TV history, ABC reported in 2004.

Geary exited “General Hospital” in 1984. He later revived the role of Luke in 1991. He retired from playing Luke in 2015, and returned one more time for a fan-favorite cameo in 2017. The character of Luke was killed offscreen in 2022.
Geary earned a record eight Daytime Emmys for outstanding lead actor in a drama for the role.
The actor told Entertainment Weekly in 2015 he once found it “very difficult” to be known mostly for his role as Luke Spencer.

“It’s not my favorite time of my life, and I don’t think it represents me as a person or an actor,” he said. “It’s kind of like whenever you are introduced, they haul out a high-school graduation picture. It can be irritating.”
Still, he added, was grateful to be a historic part of daytime television
“It’s been a really exciting ride,” he said. “In the end, it’s been well worth it.”
In more recent years, Geary lived with Gama in Amsterdam, with Gama sharing frequent glimpses of the couple's life together on his Instagram page.

title: From Figgy Pudding to Wassail: What Are the Foods in Famous Christmas Songs?
summary: Here's what you need to know about the often-sung but rarely defined foods in Christmas songs, like figgy pudding, wassail, sugar plums and roasted chestnuts.
story: Wassail might be “all over the town” this month, but what is it, exactly?

Every holiday season, carolers sing about drinking eggnog by the fire like Medieval people did, or indulging in a holiday punch or Christmas goose like any of a number of Victorian families, all of which many modern folk still enjoy.
However, some songs blaring over shopping mall speakers or the sound systems of holiday-themed bars make us wonder: What the heck is wassail? Why don’t we still eat sugar plums and roasted chestnuts?
And, perhaps most importantly, what is figgy pudding and why does Bing Crosby want it so badly?
Figgy Pudding (‘We Wish You a Merry Christmas’)
Lyric: “Now, bring us some figgy pudding and bring it right here”

Merry modern revelers sing this song without knowing that “figgy pudding” historically did not contain figs, as it was a misinterpretation of a British holiday classic — plum pudding — which is not a pudding in the American sense, but a dense, boiled dessert.

The dish that became figgy pudding was originally more on the savory side, with preserved, sweetened meat and boiled vegetables, but eventually included prunes. Also, the word “plum” eventually became a label for all dried fruits, confusing the issue further.

While stateside bakers don’t traditionally prepare this complex treat for the holidays, save for brave souls like YouTubers Tyler Williams and Safiya Nygaard in 2022, it is still regularly sold in British stores.

A version of figgy pudding being sold at luxury department store Harrods features sultanas, raisins, demerara sugar, pitted plums, figs — unlike its historical predecessor — and a butterscotch sauce, for $24.
Sugar Plums (‘’Twas the Night Before Christmas’)
Lyric: “While visions of sugar-plums danced in their heads”
Interestingly, the history of figgy pudding and sugar plums are related since they both use the word “plum” to refer to fruit or dessert.
A sugar plum is a sugar-coated candy popular in Victorian times which often had a dried fruit like a cherry or fig or nut in the center. Not a plum at all, its name referred to its size and shape.

In 2024, YouTuber Max Miller of Tasting History made sugar plums the traditional way and discovered how time-consuming it is to roll a nut in layer after layer of warm sugar until it becomes candy-coated.
This might be why sugar plums live in the lyrics of this Christmas ditty and not actually in our modern tradition.
Cup of Cheer (‘A Holly Jolly Christmas’)
Lyric: “Have a cup of cheer”

While a cup that makes you cheerful these days may be a strong cocktail made by Sam Heughan, the term doesn’t only mean adult beverages in vintage Christmas lyricism. A “cup of cheer” can also refer to hot cocoa.
Get The Recipe
Wassail (‘Gloucestershire Wassail,’ ‘Here We Come A-Wassailing’ and More)
Lyric: “Wassail! Wassail all over the town!”
The term wassail has an olde English history: The hot mulled punch, which often consists of cider, wine or ale with winter spices, comes from the words “waes hael” which means “be healthy.”

The term is also also a verb: Back in olden times, groups of revelers went door-to-door wassailing with a wassailing bowl, offering sips of drink from it for gifts at each home they visited. This tradition may seem familiar because it’s actually where Christmas caroling comes from.
Roasted Chestnuts (‘The Christmas Song’)
Lyric: “Chestnuts roasting on an open fire”

The opener to Nat King Cole’s classic rendition of “The Christmas Song” features a once-abundant treat enjoyed by early Americans during the holidays. In the 18th and 19th centuries, chestnuts were one of the most popular ingredients in early American food because of the preponderance of Chestnut trees speckling the East Coast at the time.

For this Christmas tradition, a roasted chestnut has a soft texture and some say it tastes mild and sweet with a fluffy or potato-like texture — though one social media user who isn’t a fan claims they have a “mealy” texture.

Sadly, in 1904, a fungal disease tore through chestnut tree populations in the U.S., causing them to almost go extinct and fall out of favor as a traditional treat as a result, although countries like Turkey and Italy still feature the glossy brown nut during the holidays.

title: 7 of Rob Reiner’s Best Movies and How to Watch Them
summary: Rob Reiner is known for making some of the best movies of the 1980s and 1990s. Here's how to watch classics like "Stand By Me," "When Harry Met Sally..." and more.
story: Movie fans are reeling after Rob Reiner was found dead in his Los Angeles home on Dec. 14, along with his wife, Michele.

Reiner, 78, was the son of comedy legend Carl Reiner and found fame in the 1970s on the classic sitcom “All in the Family,” created by TV legend Norman Lear, whom Reiner knew while growing up.He played Mike Stivic, nicknamed “Meathead” by Carroll O’Connor’s bigoted Archie Bunker.
For his efforts, Reiner won a pair of Emmy Awards, but his future was on the big screen as a director, where he made some of the most memorable movies of the 1980s and ‘90s.

Here’s a look at some of the essential works in Reiner’s catalog and how you can catch them. Whether you’ve seen them before or are coming in a blank slate, these are the movies that helped make Reiner a Hollywood icon.
“This Is Spinal Tap” (1984)

The term “mockumentary” is common now, but it was a novel concept when Reiner helmed this comedy classic chronicling a British heavy metal band’s disastrous tour. It was so groundbreaking that fans may have actually believed the group, portrayed by Christopher Guest, Michael McKean and Harry Shearer, was real when it was pure fiction.

“This Is Spinal Tap” marked Reiner’s big-screen directorial debut. In addition, he starred as Marty DiBergi, the filmmaker who follows the band. Reiner also directed the long-awaited sequel that came out earlier this year.
“Stand by Me” (1986)

Adapted by Stephen King’s short story “The Body,” which was featured in the same book (“Different Seasons”) as the story that turned into “The Shawshank Redemption,” this coming-of-age drama, starring River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, Wil Wheaton and Jerry O’Connell, revolves around a group of four 12-year-old boys who take a trip to find a dead body in 1959 Oregon. The film, which Reiner has said he would like to be remembered for when looking at his career, remains popular to this day, with Feldman, Wheaton and O’Connell touring the country with screenings of it.
“The Princess Bride” (1987)

“My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die.” If that quote doesn’t mean anything to you, do yourself a favor and see this movie. Based on William Goldman’s novel of the same name, this beloved film is a fairy tale about the pirate Westley’s attempt to rescue his love Buttercup from evil Prince Humperdinck. Cary Elwes, Mandy Patinkin, Robin Wright (in her film debut), Christopher Guest and Fred Savage all star.
“When Harry Met Sally...” (1989)

Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan are at the top of their game in this rom-com classic about two polar opposites who go from disliking each other to friends to a couple over the course of many years. The movie begged the question: Can men and women just be friends? It also features the all-time great movie scene set at a deli and punctuated by a woman (played by Reiner’s real-life mother) saying, “I’ll have what she’s having.”
“Misery” (1990)

Reiner went back to Stephen King in 1990, turning the author’s suspenseful masterpiece "Misery" into a movie. In the film, an author (James Caan) is saved after a car accident by his biggest fan (Kathy Bates), who holds him captive in her home. Bates won a best actress Academy Award for her role.
“A Few Good Men” (1992)

“You can’t handle the truth!” Maybe not, but we think you can handle a viewing of this movie, which features that iconic line. Tom Cruise, Jack Nicholson and Demi Moore headline an all-star cast in this drama, written by Aaron Sorkin, about a lawyer defending a pair of Marines charged with murdering a fellow Marine. The movie scored four Oscar nominations, including best picture.
“The American President” (1995)

Reiner was skilled at helming movies across genres. Like “When Harry Met Sally…,” “The American President” showcases his ability to connect with audiences in a romantic flick. In the movie, also written by Sorkin, Michael Douglas is a widowed president who falls for an environmental lobbyist (Annette Bening) during a reelection year. Michael J. Fox and Martin Sheen also star, as does Richard Dreyfuss, who reunited with Reiner after he narrated “Stand by Me.”

title: Rob Reiner Said He'd Like to Be Remembered By This 1 Film
summary: Less than three months before his death, Rob Reiner revealed the film that he’d want to be remembered for when people looked back on his career.
story: Less than three months before his death, Rob Reiner revealed the film that he’d want to be remembered for when people looked back on his career.
The 78-year-old actor and director and his wife, Michele, were found dead in their Los Angeles home on Dec. 14 from apparent stab wounds, according to a source close to the Reiner family.
In September, Reiner appeared on "Piers Morgan Uncensored," and the host asked which of the legendary director's films most stood out to him.
"People have their favorites, the cliché, 'We love all our children –even the bad ones,'" Reiner responded. "But I always say 'Stand by Me,' to me, is the one that meant the most to me."
Reiner went on to explain why the 1986 film, which he directed, held a special place in his heart.

"I don't know that it's the best. You know, it's for other people to decide. But it's the one that meant the most to me because it really is an extension of my personality and my sensibility. It has a mixture of humor and melancholy and emotion, and it's something that is closest to me of all the films I've done," he said.

"Stand by Me," which is based on a novella by Stephen King, follows four boys who set out to find a dead body in their hometown of Castle Rock, which also lends itself to the name of Reiner's production company, Castle Rock Entertainment.
Jerry O'Connell, who starred in the film as Vernon “Vern” Tessio, posted a tribute to Reiner on social media, writing, "Love you, Rob," alongside a photo of the actor and director on set.
Actor Corey Feldman, who played Teddy Duchamp, took to X, calling Reiner's death "horrible news."
Reiner was also known for his role as Michael "Meathead" Stivic in "All in the Family" and for directing hit films such as "The Story of Us" and "When Harry Met Sally ..."
Appearing on TODAY Dec. 15, Turner Classic Movies host Dave Karger compared Reiner's filmography with Ron Howard and Steven Spielberg.

“I would put him up there with Ron Howard and Steven Spielberg as far as filmmakers from our era, right — the ‘80s and ‘90s — who made a string of films that have endured as people’s favorites,” Karger said. “You ask random people, what are some of your favorite movies of all-time, chances are you’re going to hear a Rob Reiner film or two in that bunch.”

title: Rob Reiner’s Daughter Tracy Reiner Reacts to Deaths of Her Parents
summary: Rob Reiner's daughter, Tracy Reiner, has shared her reaction to the stunning death of the famed director and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner
story: Rob Reiner's daughter, Tracy Reiner, has shared her reaction to the stunning death of the famed director and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner.
Both were found dead Dec. 14 in their Los Angeles home, a source close to the family told NBC News.
“I came from the greatest family ever,” Tracy Reiner told NBC News. “I don’t know what to say, I’m in shock.”

The Los Angeles Police Department has launched an investigation after it said Dec. 14 that officials found two deceased at Reiner's Brentwood home. They did not identify them, but a source close to the Reiner family told NBC News that the couple was found dead from what appeared to be stab wounds.
Paramedics were called to Reiner’s Los Angeles home around 3:30 p.m. on Dec. 14, and then police officers were dispatched.
Deputy Police Chief Alan Hamilton told reporters that officials have not identified a suspect and that no one has been detained. He said family members will be interviewed.
A host of Hollywood stars and politicians paid tribute to Rob Reiner, 78, and Michele Singer Reiner, 65, in the wake of their stunning deaths.
“An acclaimed actor, director, producer, writer, and engaged political activist, (Rob) always used his gifts in service of others,” Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass said in a statement.
Rob Reiner was the director of classic films like "The Princess Bride," "When Harry Met Sally," "A Few Good Men," "Stand by Me," "This is Spinal Tap," "Misery" and more.
"Misery" star Kathy Bates expressed her condolences in a statement to NBC News after hearing the "terrible news."

“Absolutely devastated,” she said. “I loved Rob. He was brilliant and kind, a man who made films of every genre to challenge himself as an artist. He also fought courageously for his political beliefs. He changed the course of my life. Michelle was a gifted photographer. She shot my beautiful photos for the Misery campaign. My heart breaks for them both."

Rob Reiner also was a comedic actor known for his role on the iconic sitcom "All in the Family" and appearances in dozens of movies, including "The Wolf of Wall Street" and most recently the sequel to "Spinal Tap." He also was in four episodes of the Hulu hit "The Bear" this year.
Tracy Reiner, 61, is one of Rob Reiner's four children. She was adopted by him during his marriage to late director Penny Marshall, whom he divorced in 1981.

He and Michele Singer Reiner, whom he married in 1989, were the parents of three children, sons Nick and Jake and daughter Romy. All three of them joined their parents on the red carpet for the premiere of "Spinal Tap II: The End Continues" on Sept. 9 in Los Angeles.

In 2016, Rob Reiner directed the film called "Being Charlie" that was co-written by his son Nick. The movie follows a young man's descent and recovery from drug addiction and was based on Nick's own experiences with addiction. Nick went to rehab 17 times before he got clean at 19.
“It was very personal,” Rob Reiner told TODAY in 2016. “What I didn’t understand is the depth of what (Nick) was going through.”

title: Dave Karger Says Rob Reiner Was ‘Truly a Giant’ Like Spielberg and Ron Howard: Never ‘Really Got His Due’
summary: TCM host Dave Karger spoke to TODAY about the legacy of Rob Reiner following the director's death. he directed.
story: Rob Reiner’s death has cast a pall over Hollywood and the millions of fans he entertained with the films he directed.
Reiner, 78, and his wife, Michele, were found dead in their Los Angeles home on Dec. 14, the victims of what appears to have been a stabbing, according to a source close to the Reiner family.

Reiner’s roster of films is prolific. “Stand by Me,” “This Is Spinal Tap,” “The Princess Bride,” “When Harry Met Sally ...,” “Misery,” “A Few Good Men” and “The American President” are among his most notable and beloved movies.

“I would put him up there with Ron Howard and Steven Spielberg as far as filmmakers from our era, right — the ‘80s and ‘90s — who made a string of films that have endured as people’s favorites,” Turner Classic Movies host Dave Karger told TODAY on Dec. 15. “You ask random people, what are some of your favorite movies of all-time, chances are you’re going to hear a Rob Reiner film or two in that bunch.”
Karger said his body of work speaks for itself, despite its lack of awards recognition.

“These are movies that have really lasted through the decades, and I don’t think Rob Reiner really got his due,” he said. “His one Oscar nomination was for producing ‘A Few Good Men.’ He never got a best director Oscar nomination, so I don’t he really got his due as a filmmaker. And I think now people are going to really start appreciating all the fantastic movies he made, like never before.”

Reiner was born into show business — his father was Carl Reiner, a comedy icon who created the pioneering “Dick Van Dyke Show.” The younger Reiner's own star rose beginning in 1971 thanks to his role in "All in the Family" as Mike Stivic — nicknamed "Meathead" by Carroll O'Connor's bigoted Archie — which netted him two Emmy Awards.

“I think this whole situation is so sad and shocking to everybody because he was truly a giant in the entertainment industry, for Rob Reiner to go from son of a comedic legend, Carl Reiner, to Emmy-winning sitcom star for ‘All in the Family,’” Karger said.
Reiner played Archie’s son-in-law, who often sparred with the family patriarch. Karger said he brought the perfect touch to the part.
“‘All in the Family,’ in the 1970s, was appointment viewing every week. It was such a terrific show, a funny show, but also a show that tackled serious topics,” he said.

“And I think in many ways the Rob Reiner Meathead character was the way in for the audience. He was the new member of family, if you will. And I think Rob Reiner even understood what an important role, iconic role that was," Karger added. "At one point, he said, ‘If I ever won the Nobel Prize, the headline would say, “Meathead Wins Nobel.”’ That was really a role and a character that is going to last for decades to come.”

Reiner made a successful transition from actor to director after “All in the Family” and would go on to help bring to life other movies and shows that fans may not realize he had a hand in developing.

“He was one of the founders of Castle Rock Entertainment, which has been a real big player in the entertainment business, not only producing his own movies, but other directors’ movies like ‘The Shawshank Redemption,’” Karger said.
“He even had a hand in producing ‘Seinfeld,’" he added. "So, Rob Reiner, whether people knew it or not, was behind so many of all of our favorite TV shows and movies, for years and years."

title: Is ‘SNL’ New this Week? Here's Who’s Hosting December 13
summary: Who is hosting "SNL" tonight, Dec. 13, 2025? What to know about Josh O'Connor and Lily Allen.
story: With the end of the year quickly approaching, there are only a couple new episodes of “Saturday Night Live” on the way.

So far during Season 51, hosts Amy Poehler, Bad Bunny, Glen Powell, Sabrina Carpenter and more celebrities have appeared in Studio 8H with musical guests like Doja Cat, Olivia Dean and Role Model. They’ve acted out skits alongside “SNL” staples, like Kenan Thompson and Bowen Yang, as well as the five new featured players this season: Tommy Brennan, Jeremy Culhane, Ben Marshall, Kam Patterson and Veronika Slowikowska.

Last week, Melissa McCarthy hosted the show for the sixth time. She opened the episode by delivering a monologue celebrating her return before appearing in skits where she played a UPS delivery driver, an awkward grocery shopper and more. She was joined by musical guest Dijon.
Here's what to know about the Dec. 13 episode of "SNL."
Is There a New Episode of ‘SNL’ This Weekend?
Yes, the next new episode of Season 51 will air Saturday, Dec. 13.

The episode features first-time host Josh O’Connor, who currently stars in “Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery.” The movie, the third entry in the “Knives Out franchise,” was released in theaters on Nov. 26 and hit Netflix Dec. 12.
British singer Lily Allen will serve as musical guest and play songs from her scathing new breakup album, “West End Girl,” which she released in October.
Allen last appeared on "SNL"  as the musical guest 18 years ago, appearing alongside host Drew Barrymore in 2007 to perform songs from her debut album, "Alright, Still."
How to Watch ‘SNL’
Comedy fans can tune into “SNL” live on NBC at 11:30 p.m. The show will also be available to stream on Peacock the following day. (TODAY.com, Peacock and NBC share a parent company, NBCUniversal.)
When Is the Next New Episode of ‘SNL’?

The final new “SNL” episode of 2025 will air on Dec. 20. “Wicked: For Good” star Ariana Grande will close the season when she hosts the show for the third time. Her return to “SNL” for the 2025 Christmas episode comes just over a year after she stopped by Studio 8H for Season 50.
Cher will be the musical guest.

title: Are Mindy and Alfie a 'Thing' in 'Emily in Paris' Season 5? Ashley Park Weighs In
summary: The "Emily in Paris" Season 5 trailer shows a steamy moment between Alfie and Mindy. What does star Ashley Park say about the moment?
story: The "Emily in Paris" Season 5 trailer finds Emily Cooper lucky in love in Rome, and leaves viewers wondering if her bestie Mindy Chen is also exploring a new, albeit unexpected, romance in the Eternal City.

Early on in the trailer, Mindy, played by Ashley Park, can be seen dining out with Alfie (Lucien Laviscount), Emily's ex. Then things appear to heat up as the pair dances and almost locks lips later on in the short clip.

While interviewing stars Park and Lily Collins in Venice for a segment that airs on Dec. 15, TODAY lifestyle contributor Jill Martin asked about what's going on between Alfie and Mindy, who broke up with her boyfriend Nicolas (Paul Forman) at the end of Season 4.
"Ashley, it looks like in the trailer you're about to make out with him," Martin noted during their chat.
"What made you think we were about to make out?" Park asked mischievously.
"It was very close," Martin replied.

Viewers will have to wait until Season 5 premieres on Netflix on Dec. 18 to find out if Mindy and Alfie are romantically involved — — and how Emily would react to such a pairing. But Park offered up the following teaser in the meantime:
"I also think they have a great friendship, and that's what we see," she said, adding that the pair was dancing, so it was natural that they'd be physically close together.
"There's heat," Collins, who plays Emily, added.
"Hot dancing," Park said.
What Happened Between Emily and Alfie?

Alfie first appeared in Season 2 of "Emily in Paris" when he met Emily during a French class. The pair didn't bond right away, but they soon found common ground over being expats in Paris (Alfie is from London).

Romance quickly blossomed, and the couple seemed to really be hitting it off. Soon, they had to decide whether they were up for a long-distance romance when Alfie announced that he had to return to London for work.
Alfie ended up staying in Paris when he found work with Antoine (William Abadie). Since his relationship with Emily was a bit rocky, he didn't tell her he was staying right away.
Emily and Alfie gave things another go but ended up breaking up at the end of Season 3 after Camille (Camille Razat) and Gabriel's (Lucas Bravo) failed wedding.
During the ceremony, Camille said she couldn't marry Gabriel because he's in love with Emily. It was too much for Alfie to handle and he said he didn't want to be Emily's second choice.

In Season 4, Emily and Alfie considered getting back together but she ended up pursuing a relationship with Gabriel. When they broke up, Emily ran into Alfie and was devastated to hear that he had a new girlfriend. Later on, Emily started dating an Italian man named Marcello (Eugenio Franceschini).

title: Taylor Swift Shares Her Four-Step ‘Wind Down’ Routine After Performing the ‘Eras Tour’
summary: Taylor Swift is sharing details about the routine that helped her relax after every "Eras Tour" concert
story: Taylor Swift is sharing details about the routine that helped her relax after every "Eras Tour" concert.
At the end of the first episode of her new "End of an Era" docuseries, the singer gave viewers an inside look into how she gets out of performance mode — and it starts with drawing a bath.
Swift, who turns 36 on Dec. 13, elaborated on the routine in an interview with Stephen Colbert on its Dec. 10 episode.
The singer said she feels like a "flickering lightbulb" after every concert, which ran for more than three hours and featured upwards of 44 songs.
"I'll go back to the hotel, get out of the costume, into the bath — — immediately — into the bath," Swift said, calling it her special "mermaid time."
Next, comes food and lots of it, Swift said.
"I get the most amount of room service possible," the singer joked.
"French fries? What's the go-to?" Colbert asked.
"Yes, everything," she replied. "Everything that I want on that given night."
Swift would also sign "2,000 CDs" or so after shows because doing "tactile hand activity" helped her to mentally decompress.
"It's like when I'm doing bread stuff," she said, referring to her highly publicized habit of baking sourdough loaves for loved ones.
"My kind of 'profession,'" Swift added, putting air quotes around the word, "is coming up with ideas for stuff. So if I can turn off the ideas for a second — very exciting."
Finally, she said she typically turns on the television to watch a favorite show.
"I'll put on my 'Dateline,' do you know what I mean?" she said, prompting the audience to laugh.
When Colbert asked her about reading, Swift said she is "constantly" listening to audiobooks.
When the host asked for favorite reads, Swift instead described the "elements" of what she looks for in a book.
Swift first name-checked Daphne du Maurier's classic gothic mystery "Rebecca" as an example of a book that might intrigue her.

"If you've got like an old rambling shambles, old British mansion covered in moss or ivy, and there's a mysterious relationship and he may not be what he seems," she said as Colbert’s audience began laughing.
"And there's been a murder that has happened in the past but there's the idea of a ghost or an actual ghost," she continued.

Swift went on to hilariously describe two other book ideas that would pull her in as the audience kept laughing. One centered around a "mysterious" family living "off the coast of Maine," and the other concerned a marriage that "isn't what it seems" –— preferably told by an "unreliable narrator."
"If you've got any of that, I'm going to need to read that," she said, "and when I say read that, I am going to need someone to read that to me."

Swift's record-breaking "Eras Tour" took her all over the globe from March 2023 until its final concert in Vancouver, Canada, on Dec. 8, 2024. The tour was chronicled in her new docuseries, "Taylor Swift: The End of an Era,” which premiered Dec. 12. Two new episodes will drop Dec. 19 before the finale airs Dec. 26.

title: What Time Is 'Landman' On? How to Watch Season 2, Episode 5
summary: When does the new episode of Landman come out? Here's how to watch Season 2, Episode 5 of Landman on Paramount+.
story: Ever since "Landman" Season 2 premiered on Nov. 16, the Paramount+ series has been breaking streaming records.
The season premiere alone brought in 9.2 million global streaming views in its first two days, which made it the most watched premiere in Paramount+ history.
Now that Season 2 is halfway through, viewers are holding their breath to see what happens next.
Eager to tune in to Episode 5? Here's everything you need to know.
What Time Does Episode 5 of 'Landman' Premiere?
New episodes of "Landman" premiere exclusively on Paramount+ on Sundays.
Season 2, Episode 5 of "Landman" lands on Paramount+ at 12 a.m. ET on Sunday, Dec. 14.
What Will Happen in Episode 5?
Season 2 Episode 5 finds Tommy (Billy Bob Thornton) navigating several issues, including Cami's (Demi Moore) lawsuit and an accident on M-Text Land.
On a more positive note, Angela (Ali Larter) hosts a dinner to welcome T.L. (Sam Elliott).
Is 'Landman' Renewed for Season 3?
"Landman" viewers got an early Christmas present on Dec. 5 when Paramount announced that the series had been renewed for a third season.
The series is set in West Texas and follows roughnecks and billionaires navigating an oil boom.

title: Taylor Swift Bleeped Out the Exact Bonus She Gave Dancers in Docuseries. The Number Left Them in Tears
summary: Taylor Swift's hefty bonuses to her "Eras Tour" dancers and crew members led to tears and shock, based on new footage from docuseries "End of an Era."
story: Taylor Swift's hefty bonuses to her "Eras Tour" employees have made plenty of headlines.
Now, fans can see for themselves how the singer's backup dancers reacted when Swift personally presented them with bonus checks.
In an emotional scene from Episode 2 of the Disney+ docuseries, "The End of an Era," Swift gathers with her dancers as they hold unopened handwritten thank you letters from her.
After telling the dancers how much she appreciates their "hard work," Swift asks one of the them, Kameron Saunders, to read his letter aloud.
"Dearest Kam, we've traveled the world like we set out to do. We dazzled the crowds but we've missed family, too," Saunders reads.
"My full gratitude doesn't come from a bank, but here's — " Saunders adds before pausing to catch his breath after seeing the dollar amount of his bonus.
Saunders then finishes reading Swift's message aloud, but the docuseries censors the exact figure with a bleep.
Saunders' fellow dancers hold their hands over their eyes and mouths in shock. Some visibly cry.
Later, Swift is seen embracing the tearful dancers. "We love you so much. This is crazy," one of them tells her.

While the exact bonus amount each dancer and crew member received is unknown, it's safe to say it was a hefty amount. As some viewers online have noticed, the censored number took several seconds to say aloud. And a few have tried reading Saunders' lips to determine what the shocking figure might have been.

Overall, Swift handed out $197 million in bonuses over the course of the tour to her "Eras Tour" employees, including dancers, band members, instrument techs, hair and makeup artists, wardrobe stylists, choreographers, security personnel, truck drivers, merchandise team members, caterers, videographers, pyrotechnics techs and riggers, lighting and sound techs, production staff and assistants, carpenters and physical therapists, People reported.
After completing the American leg of her tour in August 2023, the “Lover” singer surprised her truck drivers with $100,000 bonuses.

“Her father was the one that actually presented the checks to our drivers,” Shomotion trucking company CEO Mike Scherkenbach told TODAY at the time. “And he presented handwritten letters from Taylor. It’s incredible that they would take that time, and what it means to our staff to be recognized.”
The record-breaking tour spanned the globe from March 2023 until its final concert in Vancouver, Canada, on Dec. 8, 2024.
